questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with hip pain after a fall. An X-ray of the pelvis reveals a disrupted Shenton's line as shown below. Which of the following conditions can be ruled out based on this finding?

An elderly patient with a history of an intracapsular neck of femur fracture presents with hip pain radiating to the groin and thigh, worsening with activity but improving with rest. Examination reveals restricted range of motion and tenderness in the hip. Which of the following arteries is not typically involved in the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to such a presentation?
questions.explanation:
Blood Supply Source

Description

Retinacular Vessels
  • Major supply, derived from the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries (branches of the deep femoral artery).
  • Forms an extensive network along the femoral neck.

Intraosseous Cervical Vessels
  • Secondary source, providing additional vascular support through small penetrating vessels along the femoral neck.

Artery of Ligamentum Teres
  • Tertiary source, also called the foveolar artery.
  • Supplies the femoral head via the ligamentum teres.
  • Important in younger patients or in cases of trauma.

Obturator Artery
  • Provides minor support through its acetabular branch.
  • Primarily supplies the medial thigh muscles but contributes to anastomoses around the hip joint.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with severe pain in her left hip and is unable to bear weight on the affected leg after slipping and falling at home. An X-ray reveals a fracture of the femoral neck. Using the Garden classification system for femoral neck fractures, what is the likely grade of this fracture?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Prognosis/Complications

Subcapital

Fracture just below the femoral head.

Most common; high risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion.

Transcervical

Fracture through the midportion of the femoral neck.

Intermediate risk of complications.

Basicervical

Fracture at the base of the femoral neck.

Lower risk of avascular necrosis but transitions to extracapsular fractures.

Type

Angle (Pauwels’ Angle)

Stability/Prognosis

Type 1

<30°

Most stable, best prognosis.

Type 2

30° - 50°

Moderate stability.

Type 3

>70°

Highly unstable, worst prognosis with high risk of nonunion.

Grade

Fracture Details

Trabecular Alignment

Prognosis

Grade I

Incomplete, valgus-impacted fracture.

Normal trabecular alignment.

Best prognosis.

Grade II

Complete, but without displacement.

Normal trabecular alignment.

Good prognosis with fixation.

Grade III

Complete with partial displacement.

Misalignment between head and acetabulum.

Increased risk of nonunion.

Grade IV

Complete with full displacement.

Trabecular pattern parallel but displaced.

Worst prognosis. High risk of avascular necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following points correctly differentiates between the neck of femur fracture and intertrochanteric fracture? Intertrochanteric fractures are generally more stable and have a higher chance of conservative management. Neck of femur fractures usually occur in younger patients following high-energy trauma. Neck of femur fractures are more commonly intracapsular, while intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular. Intertrochanteric fractures are typically associated with more blood loss compared to neck of femur fractures.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Neck of Femur Fracture

Intertrochanteric Fracture

Location

Intracapsular (within the joint capsule)

Extracapsular (outside the joint capsule)

Age Group

Typically after 50 years

Typically after 60 years

Sex

Female > Male

Male > Female

Common Patient Demographics

Elderly (low-energy trauma like falls)

Elderly (low-energy trauma); rare high-energy trauma in younger patients

Mechanism of Injury

Trivial, low-energy trauma (osteoporotic)

Low-energy trauma in elderly; usually requires significant trauma in younger patients

Stability

Less stable, especially if displaced

Generally unstable due to muscle forces and location

Ability to Walk

May be possible in impacted fractures

Walking is not possible due to the instability

External Rotation Deformity

Less than 45º

More than 45º

Shortening

Less than 1 inch

More than 1 inch

Blood Supply Involvement

High risk of avascular necrosis (medial circumflex artery disruption)

Lower risk of avascular necrosis

Blood Loss

Less blood loss due to intracapsular location

More blood loss due to the involvement of surrounding vascular structures

Pain, Severity, and Tenderness

Mild to moderate pain localized to the groin/hip region. Tenderness is typically felt in Scarpa’s triangle.

Severe pain, more generalized around the hip with marked tenderness over the greater trochanter. Weight-bearing is difficult or impossible.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty, total hip replacement)

Almost always requires internal fixation (e.g., dynamic hip screws, intramedullary nails)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

Malunion is more common than nonunion

questions.text: A 50-year-old male comes with pain at the hip, and limb deformity is noted in the supine position. He is diagnosed with a posterior hip dislocation after radiological examination and is reduced by the following method: Identify this method of reduction.
questions.explanation:
Stimson gravity method
  • The patient lies face down with their lower legs bent at 90 degrees over the stretcher's edge.
  • An operator applies downward pressure on the lower leg or knee, adjusting the ankle for rotation until proper alignment is achieved.

Alli’s traction method (Option A)
  • The patient is positioned supine with the knee flexed to 90 degrees.
  • An assistant stabilizes the pelvis while the operator applies traction, flexes the hip, and gently extends and externally rotates the leg to reduce the hip.

Bigelow’s method (Option C)
  • With the pelvis stabilized, the operator holds the ankle and places their forearm at the ipsilateral knee.
  • The hip is flexed to 90 degrees, adducted, and internally rotated.
  • Traction is applied, then the limb is abducted, extended, and externally rotated.

East Baltimore technique (Option D)
  • The operator stands on the affected side with an assistant on the opposite side.
  • Together, they flex and support the affected limb under the knee, stabilizing the pelvis with their free hands.
  • Traction is applied by extending the knee upward, while a third assistant holds the ankle for leverage and controls rotation, abduction, and adduction.

Classical Watson Jones method
  • This technique works for both anterior and posterior hip dislocations.
  • The limb is positioned neutrally, with the femoral head resting posterior to the acetabulum.
  • One person stabilizes the pelvis while the other applies longitudinal traction to guide the femoral head back into place.

questions.text: An increased Insall-Salvati ratio > 1.2 suggests which of the following clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Recurrent lateral displacement of the patella from its normal position. Typically occurs on the lateral side of the knee and refers to patella dislocating multiple times.

 
  • Recurrent dislocation: 2-3 episodes of patellar dislocation.
  • Habitual dislocation: Occurs with every flexion and extension of the knee.

Predisposing Factors:

Patella Alta

High-riding patella, increasing risk of dislocation due to reduced stability.

Patella Baja

Low-lying patella, less common but can affect patellar tracking.

Tight Lateral Structures

Tight iliotibial band or vastus lateralis pulls the patella laterally; commonly seen in conditions like poliomyelitis.

Genu Valgum

Increased Q angle, leading to greater lateral pressure on the patella.

Genu Recurvatum

Hyperextension of the knee, increasing instability.

Diagnosis:

Apprehension Test

Lateral pressure on the patella causes discomfort or apprehension, indicating instability.

X-ray (Blumensaat's Line)

Position of patella relative to Blumensaat's Line assesses patellar Lowermost pole above the line: Patella Alta.

  • Lowermost pole below the line: Patella Baja.

Insaal's Line/Salvetti Ratio

Ratio between patellar tendon length and patellar >Ratio of 1: Normal.

  • Ratio >1: Suggests Patella Alta.

Treatment Options:

Modified Campbell’s Operation

Lateral release procedure to address tight lateral structures, allowing for central patellar movement.

Roux-Goldthwait Procedure

Proximal realignment of the knee capsule and quadriceps to stabilize patellar tracking.

West and Soto Hall Procedure

Imvolves patellectomy (removal of the patella), which is reserved for cases with extensor lag or failure of other treatments.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who recently started playing football complains of mild knee pain in both knees following each game. Over the past few weeks, the pain has progressively worsened, becoming constant even during rest, prompting his parents to seek medical advice. There is no history of direct trauma to the knees. An X-ray reveals characteristic findings. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical removal of the accessory patellar fragment

options.label: B
options.text: Rest, activity modification, and strengthening exercises

options.label: D
options.text: Complete knee immobilization with a cast

questions.correct_answer: B. Rest, activity modification, and strengthening exercises
questions.explanation:
Definition

A congenital condition where the patella (kneecap) is divided into two separate bone segments.

Etiology
  • Failure of ossification centers to fuse during development, resulting in separate bone fragments.
  • Occurs in approximately 1-2% of the population, often bilateral.

Anatomy

Typically involves the superolateral corner of the patella.

Types

Based on the location of the secondary ossification centre,

  • Type I: Inferior pole of patella.
  • Type II: Lateral margin.
  • Type III: Superolateral (most common).

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic, but can cause anterior knee pain, especially after trauma or repetitive stress.

Diagnosis

X-ray: Shows the patella with a well-corticated fragment.

MRI: Useful for assessing associated soft tissue injury or bone edema if symptomatic.

Differential Diagnosis

Patellar fracture (differs by smooth, rounded edges in bipartite patella vs sharp edges in fractures).

Management
  • Asymptomatic: No treatment required.
  • Symptomatic: Rest, NSAIDs, physical therapy, or in severe cases, surgery (excision of fragment).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man falls on his knees and comes with complaints of pain, swelling, and abrasions over his right knee. His X-ray shows as follows: Which of the following statements is true about the management of this type of patellar fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: A plaster cylinder or extension brace is used primarily for 3-4 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Open reduction and fixation are recommended methods of treatment

options.label: C
options.text: A range-of-motion brace is used after 2 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: The fracture is repaired using the tension band principle

questions.correct_answer: B. Open reduction and fixation are recommended methods of treatment
questions.explanation:
Type of fracture

Management

Undisplaced or minimally displaced fractures
  • Generally, the extensor mechanism is intact.
  • Treatment:
    • Use a plaster cylinder or extension brace to keep the knee straight for 3–4 weeks. (Option A)
    • Perform daily quadriceps exercises.

Longitudinal fractures
  • Extensor mechanism is nearly intact, allowing for early movement.
  • Treatment:
    • Start with an extension brace or plaster cylinder.
    • Transition to a range-of-motion brace after 2 weeks. (Option C)

Comminuted (stellate) fractures
  • Extensor expansions are intact, but there’s a risk of patellofemoral joint damage.
  • Treatment:
    • Open reduction and fixation are recommended. Remove small fragments that distort the articular surface if necessary.
    • Use K-wires, mini fragment screws, cerclage wires, or sutures.
    • Employ a hinged brace for extension and unlock it for exercises.

Displaced transverse fractures

  • Entire extensor mechanism is disrupted.
  • Treatment:
    • Operative intervention is essential.
    • Expose the fracture through a longitudinal incision and repair using the tension-band principle. (Option D)
    • Reduce and transfix fragments with stiff K-wires, securing them with flexible wire.
    • Repair tears in the extensor expansions.
    • Use a plaster back-slab or hinged brace until active knee extension is regained, with daily removal for flexion exercises.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He reports severe ankle pain and is unable to bear weight. X-rays reveal a fracture in the neck of the talus, and is shown below. Based on Hawkin's classification, which type of fracture does this represent?
questions.explanation:
Type I (Option A)

Undisplaced vertical fracture neck of talus

Type II (Option B)

Displaced fracture neck + Subluxation or dislocation of subtalar joint

Type III (Option C)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the body of the talus from both ankle and subtalar joints

Type IV (Option D)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the head and body of the talus from subtalar/ankle/talonavicular joints

Undisplaced Fracture

Displaced Fracture
  • Conservative treatment
  • Below-knee plaster cast
  • For 8-10 weeks
  • Closed reduction by traction in plantar flexion and a plaster cast is put in equinus.
  • If it fails, ORIF with lag screws is done.
  • Sometimes Herbert bone screw is used:
    • Headless compression screw
    • Generally not removed

questions.text: A 30-year-old avid runner complains of a tender lump on the dorsum of his foot, just distal to the midshaft of the first metatarsal. He mentions that the pain started gradually after increasing his running distance. An X-ray image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
